Panjab Notes and Queries
EDITOR’S OFFICE
AMBÁLÁ, PANJÁB, INDIA , Dated 26-1-1884
div.p: I shall be most happy to insert your pieces in P. N.& Q.Die Panjab Notes and Queries erschienen von 1883-86 in Allahabad [u.a.]. Sie wurden1886-87 von Indian Notes and Queries fortgesetzt. & also to insert in future any notes you may be so kind as to favor me with.

Col Kenney-Herbert, Military Secretary to the Government of MadrasColonel
Arthur Robert Kenney-Herbert (1840-1916), brit. Offizier in der Indian Army, 1881-84 Military secretary to the governor of Madras. (Im HSA gibt es keine Korr, von ihm). has a very good knowledge of Butler English as known
at Madras„Butler English, also known as Bearer English or Kitchen English is a dialect of English that first developed as an occupational dialect in the years of the Madras Presedency in India, but that has developed over time and is now associated mainly with social class rather than occupation“ (wikipedia). & as he possesses considerable literary skill he might be able to help you by direct correspondence.

You may observe that I lose no opportunity of inserting instances of corrupted English in my journal &Der Autor setzt selber eine Art +-Zeichen! it is a subject I have always taken an interest in & thought more valuable than people usually suspected.

Some years ago I compiled a largish Dict. in MS. S. of corruption of English and had many hopes on the subjet in MS. but as they were
compiled in the early days of my philological studies & are therefore crude & not very learned & as these studies have since engrossed all my time I have dropped the subject to a great extent. If however my labours will be of any use to you please let me know & I’ll see what I can do towards helping you in yours.
I am however an habitually overworked man & I fear I cannot help you much.

closer.salute: I am yours trulyDie Grußformel ist nicht wirklich entzifferbar!

signed.note: Das C. im Namen ist erklärungsbedürftig, da es gewöhnlich mit seinem Sohn Sir Richard Carnac Temple (1850-1931) in Verbindung gebracht wird; bei ihm ist es der zweite Nachname der Mutter. Möglich wäre, dass auch R. C. Temple (1826-1902) diesen Nachnamenszusatz führte.
